sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Idiopathic urticaria, chronic, H1 antihistamine-refractory: 150 or 300 mg SUBQ every 4 weeks; appropriate duration of therapy has not been established
  • IgE-mediated allergic asthma, not controlled by inhaled corticosteroids: 150 to 375 mg SUBQ every 2 or 4 weeks; dosage determined by IgE level before first treatment and body weight; do not administer more than 150 mg into one injection site; do NOT use IgE level for subsequent dose determinations unless treatment has been interrupted for more than 1 year

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• Idiopathic urticaria, chronic, H1 antihistamine-refractory: 12 years or older, 150 or 300 mg SUBQ every 4 weeks; appropriate duration of therapy has not been established
  • IgE-mediated allergic asthma, not controlled by inhaled corticosteroids: 12 years or older, 150 to 375 mg SUBQ every 2 or 4 weeks; dosage determined by IgE level before first treatment and body weight; do not administer more than 150 mg into one injection site; do NOT use IgE level for subsequent dose determinations unless treatment has been interrupted for more than 1 year

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• age, 12 to 75 years: dosage adjustments not needed
  • gender: dosage adjustments not needed
  • race or ethnicity: dosage adjustments not needed

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Idiopathic urticaria, chronic, H1 antihistamine-refractory
  • IgE-mediated allergic asthma, not controlled by inhaled corticosteroids
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Allergic rhinitis; Prophylaxis
  • Allergy to peanuts
  • Latex allergy
  • Subcutaneous immunotherapy; Adjunct

2.title: Black Box Warning
2.mono:
Subcutaneous (Powder for Solution)
Anaphylaxis, presenting as bronchospasm, hypotension, syncope, urticaria, and/or angioedema of the throat or tongue, has been reported with omalizumab administration. Anaphylaxis may occur at any time from the first dose to more than a year after omalizumab initiation. Closely monitor patients after omalizumab administration and prepare to manage any anaphylactic reactions.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: severe hypersensitivity to omalizumab or any component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• anaphylactic reactions (eg, bronchospasm, hypotension, syncope, urticaria, angioedema) may occur from the first dose to more than a year after therapy initiation; monitoring recommended; discontinuation may be required
  • acute bronchospasm, acute asthma exacerbations, or status asthmaticus; do not use omalizumab for these indications
  • corticosteroid use (systemic or inhaled); avoid abrupt corticosteroid discontinuation with initiation of omalizumab
  • eosinophilic conditions (eg, vasculitis consistent with Churg-Strauss syndrome) have been rarely reported, often in association with oral corticosteroid therapy reduction
  • helminth infections may occur; monitoring recommended in high-risk patients
  • malignant neoplasms have been reported in both adults and adolescents
  • total serum IgE level elevations, persistent (ie, up to 1 year after treatment discontinuation) may impact dosing regimens in allergic asthma patients
  • serum sickness-like reaction (eg, fever, arthritis, arthralgia, rash, lymphadenopathy) has been reported 1 to 5 days after at least 1 omalizumab dose; discontinue if symptoms develop
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Injection site reaction (Allergic asthma, 45%; chronic idiopathic urticaria, 0.6% to 2.7%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Arthralgia (Allergic asthma, 8%; chronic idiopathic urticaria, 2.9%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (6.1% to 15%)
  • Respiratory:Pharyngitis (6.6% to 11%), Sinusitis (Allergic asthma, 16%; chronic idiopathic urticaria, 1.1% to 4.9%)
  • Other:Pain (Allergic asthma, 7%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Myocardial infarction, Unstable angina
  • Hematologic:Eosinophilic disorder (Rare), Venous thrombosis
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis (0.1%)
  • Neurologic:Cerebrovascular disease, Transient ischemic attack
  • Respiratory:Pulmonary embolism, Pulmonary hypertension
  • Other:Cancer (Asthma and other allergic disorders, 0.5%), Helminth infection (Patients at high risk for geohelminthic infections, 53%), Serum sickness due to drug

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Omalizumab is a recombinant humanized monoclonal antibody directed against IgE. In allergic asthma, it inhibits the binding of IgE to the high-affinity IgE receptor (RI) on the surface of mast cells and basophils, which limits the degree of release of mediators of the allergic response and also reduces the number of RI receptors on basophils in atopic patients. In chronic idiopathic urticaria, omalizumab binds to IgE and lowers free IgE levels, which down-regulates the IgE receptors on cells. It is unknown why this mechanism improves symptoms.

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Excretion: via IgG, is degraded in liver and excreted in bile
  • Total body clearance: 2.4 to 3 mL/kg/day; doubling the body weight resulted in a doubling of the apparent clearance

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Subcutaneous
  • reconstitute with sterile water for injection; gently swirl for approximately 1 minute and then for 5 to 10 seconds every 5 minutes thereafter, until completely dissolved
  • do not shake; may take 15 to 20 minutes or more to dissolve; do not use if not completely dissolved by 40 minutes
  • to ensure that all solution is removed, invert vial for 15 seconds allowing solution to drain to stopper; using a 1-inch, 18-gauge needle and a 3-mL syringe, withdraw contents of vial; before removing needle from vial, pull plunger back to the end of the syringe barrel to remove all solution
  • replace 18-gauge needle with a 25-gauge needle before administration
  • administration may take 5 to 10 seconds due to product viscosity
  • administer no more than 150 mg at one injection site

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• baseline serum IgE levels in patients with allergic asthma; retesting levels during treatment cannot be used for dose determination; if therapy is interrupted for 1 year or longer, retest total serum IgE levels; in patients with chronic idiopathic urticaria, IgE levels are not useful
  • reduction in asthma exacerbations or urticaria severity may be indicative of efficacy
  • anaphylaxis; during and after administration; may occur following the first dose; time to anaphylaxis onset range, 90 minutes to 2 hours in clinical studies; has also occurred 1 year following initial treatment
  • systemic eosinophilia symptoms (ie, eosinophilia, vasculitic rash, worsening pulmonary symptoms, and cardiac neuropathy); especially during oral corticosteroid dose reductions
  • stool assessment for parasitic helminths (roundworm, hookworm, whipworm, threadworm); during therapy in patients with high risk; duration of monitoring required after discontinuation of therapy is not known
  • significant body weight changes in patients with allergic asthma

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Instruct patient to get emergency medical treatment right away if any signs/symptoms of anaphylaxis develop and that symptoms can occur 24 hours or longer after drug administration.
  • Advise patient that this drug is not indicated for acute asthma attacks, acute bronchospasm, or status asthmaticus.
  • This drug may cause headaches.
  • Advise patient that full symptomatic improvement may not occur immediately.
